all</text><text start="49.219" dur="5.051">I&#39;m sure the nation will join me in

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="0" dur="5">[Musik] Eigentlich wollte ich heute ein Video 
machen zur dunklen Energie. Und was das Universum</text><text start="6" dur="4">auseinander treibt. Aber das Corona-Virus hat 
natürlich alles auf den Kopf gestellt. </text><text start="11" dur="4">Und dann geht&#39;s um was ganz anderes, nämlich was
unsere Gesellschaft auseinander treibt. Auf der </text><text start="16" dur="4">einen Seite einschneidende Quarantänemaßnahmen, 
auf der anderen Seite Meldungen, dass sei alles </text><text start="21" dur="8">nur Hysterie, dass sei alles übertrieben. 
[Intro]</text><text start="30" dur="5">Möglicherweise rede ich heute über etwas, worüber
wir in einem Monat nur milde lächeln werden. Aber</text><text start="36" dur="3">zurzeit kann man nicht drüber lächeln, denn es 
gibt Meldungen im Netz, da heißt es: </text><text start="40" dur="7">Hätte man das SARS-CoV-19 nicht entdeckt, wäre uns
der Ausbruch der Pandemie gar nicht aufgefallen.</text><text start="48" dur="6">Also mit anderen Worten: Wenn es keine Möglichkeit
gäbe dieses Virus tatsächlich zu entdecken, über</text><text start="55" dur="4">die entsprechenden Tests, dann hätten wir es über-
haupt nicht gemerkt. Wir würden heute einfach noch</text><text start="60" dur="4">genauso weitermachen wie bisher. Das ist praktisch
der Kern einer Botschaft, die mit ein paar </text><text start="65" dur="3">Verschwörungstheorien garniert, jetzt inzwischen 
sich im Netz rumtreibt. Und ich weiß gar nicht</text><text start="69" dur="3">wie viele Anfragen ich schon bekommen habe dazu
und das wollen wir doch jetzt mal klären. </text><text start="73" dur="5">Also um mal zu verstehen, wie man auf diese Idee
kommen kann, dass es einen weltweiten Hype um </text><text start="79" dur="8">einen Virus geben könnte: Es gab im Jahr 2009/2010
die sogenannte Schweinegrippe. Und da hat die </text><text start="88" dur="5">Weltgesundheitsorganisation auch eine Pandemie
ausgerufen. Also praktisch genauso wie jetzt. Nur</text><text start="94" dur="3">es hat sich gar keine entwickelt. Es war eine der
schwächsten Grippewellen aller Zeiten.</text><text start="98" dur="5">Also es gab gerade mal in Europa 3.000 Tote dazu.
In ganz Europa. Und bei uns in Deutschland </text><text start="104" dur="4">sterben jeden Tag 2.500 Personen. Und bei einer 
normalen Grippewelle zum Beispiel sind eben im</text><text start="109" dur="6">Winter schonmal 40.000 Tote mehr. Und wie ist es
jetzt aktuell? Wie sind jetzt die Zahlen? Naja,</text><text start="116" dur="5">in ganz Europa sind 4.000 Leute gestorben. Das ist
doch alles noch irgendwie in der Größenordnung,</text><text start="122" dur="6">die erwartbar ist. Das ist das Argument derjenigen
die meinen, das alles sei alles Hysterie. </text><text start="129" dur="4">Das sei alles total übertrieben. Machen wir Sta-
tistik! Und gehen den Zahlen mal tatsächlich auf</text><text start="134" dur="7">den Grund. Normalerweise, sterben in Italien bei
einer Gesamtbevölkerung von 60 Millionen Menschen,</text><text start="142" dur="5">jeden Tag etwa 2.000 Personen. Das schwankt na-
türlich mit den Jahreszeiten. </text><text start="148" dur="8">Gestern, am 18. März 2020 
waren es 475 Tote mehr.</text><text start="157" dur="7">Das heißt, wir haben eine Steigerung um deutlich

captions:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="0.59" dur="1.692">On November 5th, 2020,</text><text start="2.282" dur="2.878">the United Kingdom
went into lockdown.</text><text start="5.16" dur="3.592">They were trying to control
a spike in Covid-19 cases.</text><text start="8.752" dur="2.458">And, if you look at
the chart of cases,</text><text start="11.21" dur="2.51">it seemed to work.</text><text start="13.72" dur="3.117">But, despite having the same
lockdown measures,</text><text start="16.837" dur="5.023">infections in Kent, an area
outside of London, were still rising.</text><text start="21.86" dur="5.542">In early December, the overall drop in cases
led the country to relax restrictions anyway.</text><text start="27.402" dur="3.954">And then this happened.</text><text start="31.356" dur="2.684">It wasn’t until around this time
that researchers realized</text><text start="34.04" dur="4.04">that somewhere in Kent,
the virus itself had changed.</text><text start="38.08" dur="1.92">It was a new variant.</text><text start="40" dur="1.719">It was more contagious.</text><text start="41.719" dur="2.546">And it was spreading.</text><text start="44.265" dur="4.735">By the time scientists gave it a name,
it had spread to most of southeast England.</text><text start="49" dur="3.16">Two months later,
it was in 30 other countries.</text><text start="52.16" dur="5.655">Five months later, it was the most common
form of the virus found in the United States.</text><text start="57.815" dur="5.115">Lately, more and more variants are emerging
in various places around the world.</text><text start="62.93" dur="3.172">So why are they showing up now?</text><text start="66.102" dur="4.382">And what does this mean for the pandemic?</text><text start="72.697" dur="1.962">Viruses are very simple.</text><text start="74.659" dur="4.027">They’re basically just a shell of protein
surrounding some genetic material:</text><text start="78.686" dur="2.61">either DNA or RNA.</text><text start="81.296" dur="2.463">That genetic material
is made up of molecules</text><text start="83.759" dur="3.95">that can be represented as
a series of letters, like this.</text><text start="87.709" dur="2.34">Each part of this code contains instructions</text><text start="90.049" dur="4.22">for how to make one specific protein
that allows the virus to function.</text><text start="94.269" dur="3.64">A virus has one goal:
to make more of itself.</text><text start="97.909" dur="4.091">But because it’s so simple,
it can’t do that on its own.</text><text start="102" dur="2.459">So it uses you.</text><text start="104.459" dur="4.96">Every time a virus infects a person,
it uses their cells to make copies of itself--</text><text start="109.419" dur="5.23">replicating this complex code
again, and again, and again.</text><text start="114.649" dur="3.132">But eventually,
it makes a mistake.</text><text start="117.781" dur="2.28">Sometimes it deletes
or adds a letter.</text><text start="120.061" dur="2.118">Sometimes it flips them around.</text><text start="122.179" dur="1.9">That mistake is called a mutation,</text><text start="124.079" dur="3.43">and it slightly changes the instructions
for making the virus.</text><text start="127.509" dur="4.179">That slightly altered virus
is a variant.</text><text start="131.688" dur="3.031">Since viruses are constantly going
through this copying process,</text><text start="134.719" dur="2.717">it’s normal for them
to change over time.</text><text start="137.436" dur="3.074">For example, this chart shows
some of the mutations</text><text start="140.51" dur="4.473">the SARS_CoV2 virus has made
since December of 2019.</text><text start="144.983" dur="4.146">Most of the time, these mutations are harmless,
or even make the virus weaker,</text><text start="149.129" dur="4.091">and they quietly disappear without
making any notable difference.</text><text start="153.22" dur="5.571">But other times, a series of mutations occur
that give the virus a slight edge over us.</text><text start="158.791" dur="5.09">Which is what scientists started to notice
with SARS_CoV2, back in September of 2020.</text><text start="163.881" dur="2.909">“You&#39;re seeing specific mutations
that do allow the virus</text><text start="166.79" dur="3.71">to bind human receptors better,
and enter cells better.”</text><text start="170.5" dur="2.404">Coronaviruses are covered
in spike proteins,</text><text start="172.904" dur="3.645">that they use to bind with
and infect human cells.</text><text start="176.549" dur="2.77">The thing is, that binding
isn’t a perfect fit.</text><text start="179.319" dur="3.36">So it doesn’t always get
past the cell’s defenses.</text><text start="182.679" dur="4.409">But the B.1.1.7 variant, which scientists
later renamed the “Alpha” variant,</text><text start="187.088" dur="2.834">has multiple mutations
on the spike protein:</text><text start="189.922" dur="3.775">Mutations that make it easier
for the virus to bind with cells.</text><text start="193.697" dur="3.382">Which can help make
the virus more transmissible.</text><text start="197.079" dur="5.821">Which led it to become a dominant strain
in many places around the world.</text><text start="202.9" dur="3.236">But if SARS_CoV2 has
been mutating all along,</text><text start="206.136" dur="2.702">why do the variants today,
like this Alpha variant,</text><text start="208.838" dur="3.249">suddenly seem
so much worse?</text><text start="213.692" dur="4.572">It’s important to remember that a virus
doesn’t make active decisions.</text><text start="218.264" dur="3.312">It’s not as if it creates a
strategy within your cells.</text><text start="221.576" dur="3.624">Mutations are random errors.</text><text start="225.2" dur="3.759">But the longer a virus is around,
and the more people it infects,</text><text start="228.959" dur="1.516">the more it will change.</text><text start="230.475" dur="1.975">And the more those
changes accumulate,</text><text start="232.45" dur="4.472">the more chances the virus has to evolve
into something more dangerous.</text><text start="236.922" dur="4.262">These four variants, considered “variants of
concern” by the World Health Organization,</text><text start="241.184" dur="3.032">all have mutations
on the spike protein.</text><text start="244.216" dur="4.784">Delta, the most recent addition to this list,
has been referred to as a “double mutant,”</text><text start="249" dur="5.864">because, while it has many different mutations,
it has two significant ones we’ve seen before:</text><text start="254.864" dur="3.452">This mutation seems to make
the virus more transmissible.</text><text start="258.316" dur="3.038">And a version of this one,
found in two other variants,</text><text start="261.354" dur="5.34">makes it easier for the virus to reinfect
people who have already had Covid-19--</text><text start="266.694" dur="6.787">meaning, these two mutations may have
evolved to dodge our natural immune response.</text><text start="273.481" dur="2.669">Fortunately, the immune response
we get from the vaccines</text><text start="276.15" dur="3.985">is much stronger than our body’s
natural immune response.</text><text start="280.135" dur="5.083">So, while we may see variants that make
our vaccines somewhat less effective,</text><text start="285.218" dur="5.487">most experts think it’s unlikely one will emerge
that completely evades our vaccines.</text><text start="290.705" dur="3.745">But that doesn’t mean it can’t happen.</text><text start="294.45" dur="4.379">“If you give the virus enough
time and replicative cycles,</text><text start="298.829" dur="4.121">it will sample a very large
evolutionary space,</text><text start="302.95" dur="4.48">and find a solution to the
problem we&#39;ve presented it--</text><text start="307.43" dur="3.34">which is vaccination
and widespread immunity.”</text><text start="310.77" dur="3.17">But even if SARS_CoV2
doesn’t get to that point,</text><text start="313.94" dur="5.06">as long as the pandemic continues,
and as long as the virus continues to spread,</text><text start="319" dur="3.16">it will continue to make copies of itself.</text><text start="322.16" dur="3.77">So if we want to stop the variants,</text><text start="325.93" dur="2.346">we need to stop the virus.</text><text start="330.607" dur="4.73">The virus has evolved. But it hasn’t
morphed into something unrecognizable.</text><text start="335.337" dur="4.433">The vaccines we have still
protect against all the variants.</text><text start="339.77" dur="4.495">The trouble is, we aren’t getting those
vaccines around the world fast enough.</text><text start="344.265" dur="2.545">Which is only giving the virus
more time to change,</text><text start="346.81" dur="4.47">and ravage areas of the world
that are still waiting.</text><text start="351.28" dur="3.816">The rise of variants is a reminder
that the pandemic isn’t over.</text><text start="355.096" dur="3.446">Even if it feels like
it is to some of us.</text><text start="358.542" dur="3.368">“We need to stop this, because we
don’t want a variant that affects immunity.</text><text start="361.91" dur="3.845">And so that involves stopping
replication everywhere.”</text></transcript>

captions: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="0.04" dur="9.389">कि सूर्य नमस्कार सूर्य पृथ्वी पर रहने</text><text start="6.009" dur="6.84">वाले सभी जीवों के लिए ऊर्जा का स्रोत है</text><text start="9.429" dur="6.811">सूर्य नमस्कार हमारे शरीर का संपूर्ण और</text><text start="12.849" dur="6.561">संतुलित विकास करता है मन को एकाग्रता और</text><text start="16.24" dur="5.43">बुद्धि को कुशाग्र अ करने में मदद करता है</text><text start="19.41" dur="5.91">आध्यात्मिक उन्नति के लिए सूर्य नमस्कार</text><text start="21.67" dur="7.98">को महत्वपूर्ण माना गया है सूर्य नमस्कार</text><text start="25.32" dur="7.24">आज अलग-अलग आसनों की मदद से 12 चरणों में</text><text start="29.65" dur="5.79">क्रम से किया जाता है सूर्योदय और</text><text start="32.56" dur="5.54">सूर्यास्त के समय से करना ज्यादा फायदेमंद</text><text start="35.44" dur="2.66">होता है</text><text start="38.94" dur="6.27">हैं सबसे पहले आप अपने दोनों पैरों को आपस</text><text start="42.3" dur="5.849">में जोड़ते हुए बिना कानों को झुकाएं सीधे</text><text start="45.21" dur="6.059">खड़े हो चाहे सुनिश्चित करें कि आपके हाथ</text><text start="48.149" dur="6.3">शरीर के समीप हों और आपकी थोड़ी जमीन से</text><text start="51.269" dur="6.57">समानांतर योग अपने शरीर को दोनों पैरों पर</text><text start="54.449" dur="6.96">समान रूप से संतुलित करें इस स्थिति को</text><text start="57.839" dur="6.991">समझ स्थिति कहा जाता है पहले चरण को करने</text><text start="61.409" dur="6.63">के लिए सांस लेते हुए अपने दोनों हाथों को</text><text start="64.83" dur="5.91">आपस में जोड़े और अपनी छाती के समीप</text><text start="68.039" dur="7.521">नमस्कार मुद्रा में ले आए इसे प्रणामासन</text><text start="70.74" dur="8.4">कहा जाता है अब सांस छोड़ें दूसरे चरण में</text><text start="75.56" dur="7.27">धीरे-धीरे सांस अंदर लेते हुए अपने शरीर</text><text start="79.14" dur="6.119">को कमर से ऊपर की ओर खींचें और अपने दोनों</text><text start="82.83" dur="6.65">हाथों को अपने सिर के ऊपर ले जाते हुए</text><text start="85.259" dur="8.331">अपने सर और कमर को पीछे की ओर झुका है</text><text start="89.48" dur="6.6">मैं अपनी टांगें सीधी रखें इस आसन को हस्त</text><text start="93.59" dur="5.91">उत्तानासन कहा जाता है</text><text start="96.08" dur="6.9">तो अब तीसरे चरण के लिए धीरे-धीरे सांस</text><text start="99.5" dur="7.17">छोड़ते हुए अपने शरीर को आगे की ओर तब तक</text><text start="102.98" dur="6.75">झुकाएं जब तक आपकी दोनों हथेलियां आपके</text><text start="106.67" dur="6.54">पैरों के दोनों तरफ ज़मीन को छूना गए</text><text start="109.73" dur="7.29">ध्यान रखें कि नीचे जपते समय आपके वह जाएं</text><text start="113.21" dur="8.04">और सर एक ही साथियों इस आसन को पादहस्तासन</text><text start="117.02" dur="8.07">कहा जाता है चौथे चरण को करने के लिए एक</text><text start="121.25" dur="8.25">गहरी सांस अंदर ली और अपने दाएं पैर को</text><text start="125.09" dur="7.98">पीछे की ओर ले जाएं और अपने घुटने को जमीन</text><text start="129.5" dur="6.81">पर सटाकर रखें सुनिश्चित करें कि आपका</text><text start="133.07" dur="6.72">दायां पैर पंजों पर हो आपका पाया पैर का</text><text start="136.31" dur="7.23">घुटना 90 डिग्री पर हो दोनों हथेलियां</text><text start="139.79" dur="7.8">जमीन पर हूं आपके कुएं नीचे और थोड़ी ऊपर</text><text start="143.54" dur="7.2">की ओर हो इस आसन को अश्व संचालनासन कहते</text><text start="147.59" dur="6.869">हैं अब पांचवें चरण में एक गहरी सांस</text><text start="150.74" dur="5.32">छोड़ते हुए अपना पाया पैर इस प्रकार पीछे</text><text start="154.459" dur="4.481">ले जाएं कि वह आपके</text><text start="156.06" dur="6.929">अपने पैर की स्पीड में हो सुनिश्चित करें</text><text start="158.94" dur="7.92">कि आपके हाथ और कंधे सीधी रेखा में हो और</text><text start="162.989" dur="7.741">साथ ही गंध जेड पीठ और नितंब भी एक ही</text><text start="166.86" dur="9.9">सीमित हो इस आसन को संतुलन हसन कहा जाता</text><text start="170.73" dur="9.539">है इस स्थिति में धीरे-धीरे सांस लें छठा</text><text start="176.76" dur="6.93">चरण सांस छोड़ें अब अपने दोनों घुटनों को</text><text start="180.269" dur="6.811">एक साथ जमीन पर रखें और अपनी छाती और माथे</text><text start="183.69" dur="7.019">को भी जमीन पर रखिए सुनिश्चित करें कि</text><text start="187.08" dur="6.55">आपके कूल्हे ऊपर की ओर और आपकी कोहनियां</text><text start="190.709" dur="6.371">आपके शरीर के समीप हो</text><text start="193.63" dur="6.9">कि इस आसन को साष्टांग नमस्कार आसन कहा</text><text start="197.08" dur="6.96">जाता है क्योंकि आपके शरीर के आठ अलग-अलग</text><text start="200.53" dur="7.8">अंगों जैसे दोनों पैरों के पंजे दोनों</text><text start="204.04" dur="7.32">कोर्ट ने दोनों हथेलियां छाती और मां था</text><text start="208.33" dur="6.36">ज़मीन को छूते हैं ध्यान रखें कि आपके</text><text start="211.36" dur="6.96">शरीर का वजन 600 अंगों पर सामान्य रूप से</text><text start="214.69" dur="7.17">वितरित हो अब सातवें चरण के लिए सांस अंदर</text><text start="218.32" dur="7.05">लेते हुए अपनी सूनी यानि टेलीस्कोप नीचे</text><text start="221.86" dur="6.75">लगाएंगे अपने सर और छाती को आगे की ओर</text><text start="225.37" dur="7.11">सरकारें और अपने शरीर के ऊपरी हिस्से को</text><text start="228.61" dur="8.46">ना भी तक उठाएं सुनिश्चित करें आपके पैरों</text><text start="232.48" dur="7.72">के पंजे बाहर की ओर टांगें सीधी हो इस आसन</text><text start="237.07" dur="7.15">को भुजंगासन कहा जाता है</text><text start="240.2" dur="7.5">है आठवां चरण धीरे-धीरे सांस छोड़ते हुए</text><text start="244.22" dur="6.48">अपने पैरों के पंजों को अंदर की ओर मुड़े</text><text start="247.7" dur="6.72">और अपने कूल्हों को इतना ऊपर ले जाएं कि</text><text start="250.7" dur="6.9">आपका शरीर एक पर्वत का आकार ले सुनिश्चित</text><text start="254.42" dur="6.83">करें आपकी दोनों टांगें सीधी हथेलियां</text><text start="257.6" dur="7.44">जमीन पर हूं और आपका सर भुजाओं के बीच हो</text><text start="261.25" dur="9.79">प्रयास करें कि आपकी एड़ियां जमीन को छू</text><text start="265.04" dur="9.42">सके इस आसन को पर्वतासन कहा जाता है नौवें</text><text start="271.04" dur="7.59">चरण के लिए अपने कूल्हों को नीचे लाएं और</text><text start="274.46" dur="7.08">सांस लेते हुए दाहिने पैर को आगे लाएं और</text><text start="278.63" dur="7.42">अपने बाएं पैर के घुटने को जमीन पर रखते</text><text start="281.54" dur="7.719">हुए उन हक अश्व संचालनासन में आ जाएं है</text><text start="286.05" dur="6.149">के दसवें चरण में अपना बाया पैर भी आगे</text><text start="289.259" dur="7.321">लाएं और सांस छोड़ते हुए उन्हें</text><text start="292.199" dur="7.5">पादहस्तासन में आ जाए 11वां चरण अब</text><text start="296.58" dur="6.809">धीरे-धीरे सांस अंदर लेते हुए अपने शरीर</text><text start="299.699" dur="7.411">को सीधा करते हुए अपने दोनों हाथों को ऊपर</text><text start="303.389" dur="7.71">की ओर ले जाएं और उन हलस्तों तनाव में आ</text><text start="307.11" dur="9.17">जाए सुनिश्चित करें कि ऊपर आते समय आपकी</text><text start="311.099" dur="8.401">भुजाएं और सर साथ में ऊपर आए बार व</text><text start="316.28" dur="5.92">धीरे-धीरे सांस छोड़ते हुए उन्हें प्रणाम</text><text start="319.5" dur="5.73">आसन में सीधे खड़े हो जाएंगे</text><text start="322.2" dur="6.63">कि अब इस पूरे अनुक्रम को अपने बाएं पैर</text><text start="325.23" dur="6.66">से दोहा सूर्य नमस्कार से आपके फेफड़ों की</text><text start="328.83" dur="6.24">क्षमता बढ़ती है सूर्य नमस्कार आपके मैटअप</text><text start="331.89" dur="6.27">लिजम में सुधार लाता है और मधुमेह के</text><text start="335.07" dur="5.73">प्रबंधन में उपयोगी पाया गया है सूर्य</text><text start="338.16" dur="4.89">नमस्कार अंत स्रावी ग्रंथियों या ने</text><text start="340.8" dur="6.48">इंडोक्राइन बैलेंस के स्राव को नियंत्रित</text><text start="343.05" dur="7.11">करता है सूर्य नमस्कार आपको वजन को सही</text><text start="347.28" dur="5.55">रखने में मदद करता है और आपके मेरुदंड और</text><text start="350.16" dur="6.18">आपके कमर की मांसपेशियों को मजबूती title: CDC COVID-19 Prevention Messages for Front Line Long-Term Care Staff: Clean Hands – Combat COVID-19
description: Keep Long-term Care and Nursing Home residents healthy by knowing how and when to perform hand hygiene as part of ...
channelTitle: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
tags: CDC;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;Public Health;Government;Long-term care;nursing homes;COVID-19;coronavirus;clean hands;hand washing;staff;front line;hand hygiene;prevent the spread;train;Ready
captions:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="0.036" dur="5.08">&gt;&gt; Hi, my name is Nimalie Stone,
and I&#39;m one of the CDC leads</text><text start="5.256" dur="3.44">for the COVID-19 response in
long-term care facilities.</text><text start="9.716" dur="2.01">Today, we are going to talk</text><text start="11.726" dur="3.26">about how clean hands
combat COVID-19</text><text start="15.506" dur="4.48">and discuss some key points
for understanding the role</text><text start="19.986" dur="3.22">of hand hygiene in
COVID-19 prevention.</text><text start="24.736" dur="4.28">This is part of the
key, COVID-19 messages</text><text start="29.016" dur="2.94">for frontline long-term
care staff.</text><text start="38.316" dur="2.62">The residents you care
for in nursing homes</text><text start="40.936" dur="3.51">and assisted living facilities
are the most vulnerable</text><text start="44.596" dur="1.61">to COVID-19 infection.</text><text start="47.406" dur="3.82">Because of their age, frailty,
and chronic medical needs,</text><text start="51.226" dur="3.36">nursing home residents
are more likely</text><text start="54.586" dur="5.91">to have severe illness leading
to hospitalization and death,</text><text start="60.496" dur="4.78">8 out of every 10 deaths
from COVID-19 has occurred</text><text start="65.276" dur="4.05">in adults over 65 years of age.</text><text start="69.566" dur="2.4">We all must take action
now to protect them.</text><text start="76.046" dur="2.74">You&#39;ve probably heard a lot
about hand hygiene before,</text><text start="79.756" dur="3.2">but did you know that
nursing staff can touch</text><text start="82.956" dur="4.27">up to 15 different
surfaces during a single</text><text start="87.476" dur="1.68">care interaction?</text><text start="90.256" dur="3.27">That means an average
nurse working</text><text start="93.526" dur="4.68">with five residents each hour
would be expected to touch</text><text start="98.236" dur="3.63">over 900 surfaces
during a shift.</text><text start="102.696" dur="5.7">Viruses, like the Coronavirus
causing COVID-19 bacteria,</text><text start="108.916" dur="4.85">including C. diff and other
germs can all be spread</text><text start="113.906" dur="3.82">from our hands to our
residents, their care equipment,</text><text start="118.346" dur="2.03">and other surfaces in the room.</text><text start="122.036" dur="4.3">Cleaning our hands often during
these interactions contains</text><text start="126.336" dur="0.6">their spread.</text><text start="131.336" dur="3.89">There are four important moments
when you must clean your hands;</text><text start="136.236" dur="4.7">before any contact with a
resident or their environment,</text><text start="142.996" dur="2.43">before every clean procedure,</text><text start="145.556" dur="3.98">such as placing a urinary
catheter or peripheral IV,</text><text start="152.776" dur="3.49">after handling soiled
items or body fluids,</text><text start="157.156" dur="4.16">including after emptying a
urinary catheter collection bag,</text><text start="161.826" dur="5.62">and after teaching the resident
or his or her environment.</text><text start="168.996" dur="3.33">If you clean your hands
at each of these moments,</text><text start="173.956" dur="3.02">you will be doing your best
to protect your facility.</text><text start="183.306" dur="1.89">You&#39;ve probably had
many in-services</text><text start="185.196" dur="3.76">about hand hygiene
technique, but did you know</text><text start="189.136" dur="3.28">that alcohol based hand
sanitizers are preferred</text><text start="192.956" dur="3.88">by the CDC for most hand
hygiene opportunities?</text><text start="198.176" dur="4.28">And washing is recommended
when hands are visibly dirty</text><text start="203.286" dur="4.78">or contaminate, such as
after caring for residents</text><text start="209.036" dur="1.75">with infectious causes
of diarrhea,</text><text start="211.646" dur="2.24">like norovirus or C. diff.</text><text start="219.046" dur="3.03">Why does CDC prefer alcohol
based hand sanitizers?</text><text start="222.756" dur="3.16">Well, it&#39;s because they
are extremely effective</text><text start="225.916" dur="2.52">against Coronavirus, influenza,</text><text start="228.436" dur="3.23">and many antibiotic
resistant germs.</text><text start="233.036" dur="5.66">In fact, studies have shown,
hand sanitizer is more effective</text><text start="239.216" dur="1.82">than washing hands
with soap and water.</text><text start="242.256" dur="3.43">Why? Because the
alcohol hand [inaudible]</text><text start="245.686" dur="3.51">and gels start killing
germs immediately.</text><text start="250.576" dur="4.2">These products are easy to use
because they coat the surfaces</text><text start="254.776" dur="4.54">of your hands and aren&#39;t
relying on perfect technique</text><text start="260.526" dur="3.67">or a certain amount
of time, also,</text><text start="264.616" dur="2.87">you can put up hand
sanitizer dispensers all</text><text start="267.486" dur="2.33">over the building,
at the bedside even,</text><text start="270.596" dur="1.83">which is hard to do with sinks.</text><text start="273.196" dur="4.28">And the good news is that hand
sanitizers are less drying</text><text start="277.976" dur="1.64">and less hard on your skin</text><text start="280.046" dur="2.93">than constantly washing your
hands with soap and water.</text><text start="287.276" dur="1.33">We don&#39;t always think
about time,</text><text start="289.296" dur="4">but our nails can actually
provide a safe space for germs</text><text start="293.296" dur="4.69">to hide, away from the killing
effects of soap or sanitizers,</text><text start="299.516" dur="3.89">although we all enjoy pampering
our hands with manicures,</text><text start="304.526" dur="4.07">people taking care of residents
should really avoid artificial</text><text start="309.406" dur="2.33">nails and keep their
natural nails trimmed,</text><text start="313.136" dur="2.67">that way we aren&#39;t
taking a chance</text><text start="315.866" dur="4.1">that our hand hygiene isn&#39;t
effectively getting rid</text><text start="320.126" dur="0.95">of all the germs.</text><text start="324.696" dur="2.61">We all use a lot of gloves
during resident care,</text><text start="328.146" dur="2.98">but we have to remember that
while gloves protect our hands,</text><text start="331.666" dur="2.2">they are not a substitute
for hand hygiene.</text><text start="334.936" dur="3.71">We should be cleaning our hands
after every glove removal,</text><text start="339.206" dur="3.65">and making sure we don&#39;t
accidentally use the same pair</text><text start="342.856" dur="2.63">of gloves with more
than one resident.</text><text start="346.996" dur="4.27">We don&#39;t realize how much
we touch faces, our hair,</text><text start="351.266" dur="3.54">or our clothing during
the day, so be mindful</text><text start="354.806" dur="3.63">of what you&#39;re touching and
definitely don&#39;t teach yourself</text><text start="358.436" dur="2.69">or reach into your
pocket with gloved hands.</text><text start="362.676" dur="3.52">Also, although we are
trying to conserve our use</text><text start="366.536" dur="1.49">of personal protective
equipment,</text><text start="369.436" dur="2.81">we should not be washing
glove with soap and water</text><text start="372.836" dur="1.13">to try to use them again.</text><text start="378.296" dur="5.5">So remember, clean hands
protect everyone; you,</text><text start="384.276" dur="2.63">your residents, and
even your family.</text><text start="388.046" dur="2.63">Do your part to stop
the spread of COVID-19</text><text start="391.466" dur="1.44">by cleaning your
hands frequently</text><text start="393.426" dur="2.85">and reminding others
to do the same.</text><text start="396.276" dur="2.86">We are all in this together
and sometimes it helps</text><text start="399.136" dur="2.24">to have a friendly
reminder when we get busy.</text><text start="402.536" dur="2.87">Support your residents in
cleaning their hands too,</text><text start="405.866" dur="3.86">before meals, after toileting,
and throughout the day.</text><text start="410.696" dur="2.71">If they have clean
hands, then everything</text><text start="413.406" dur="2.31">around them also stays
a little cleaner.</text><text start="416.976" dur="4.29">Bring your good hand hygiene
practices home as well so you,</text><text start="421.266" dur="2.71">your family, and your
community, all stay safe.</text><text start="428.106" dur="2.87">Here are links to a variety
of resources available</text><text start="430.976" dur="5.06">on the CDC website, they provide
more information about COVID-19,</text><text start="436.836" dur="2.14">additional guidance and tools.</text><text start="443.256" dur="0.41">Thank you.</text></transcript>

title: How to Do an At-Home COVID-19 Rapid Antigen Test Correctly
description: Please note that not all tests are the same. Read through the instructions included with the test before you begin. At-home rapid ...
tags: UC Davis Health;at home test;covid-19;covid test;at home covid test;rapid antigen;rapid test;home test;home covid test;coronavirus;on/go;ihealth;self test;15 minutes;10 minutes;how to use a rapid covid test;how to use an at home test;nasal swab;nose swab;how to use a nose swab;covid test for kids;usps;federal covid test;government covid test;fda;binax now;antigen test;california;sacramento;emergency room;omicron;delta;variant;covid test at home
captions:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="0.32" dur="4.96">Hi. My name is Claudio Alvarado and I work in 
an emergency department here at UC Davis Health. </text><text start="5.28" dur="2.88">Today i&#39;m going to show you 
how to do a home COVID-19 test.</text><text start="10.64" dur="4.88">The kit we&#39;ll be using is called iHealth 
COVID-19 antigen rapid test, which is a fairly  </text><text start="15.52" dur="5.28">common test to use at home. In the kit comes two 
tests and we&#39;ll go over each part of it. </text><text start="20.8" dur="1.43">You&#39;ll have your collection swab,</text><text start="22.23" dur="3.504">your test card and your dropper and liquid that you use later.</text><text start="25.734" dur="4.263">Before you begin, it&#39;s always really important to look at 
the instructions as some tests can be different.</text><text start="29.997" dur="4.483">Make sure you wash your hands thoroughly 
with warm water and soap for 30 seconds.</text><text start="35.12" dur="3.76">The first step is we&#39;re going to use a 
collection swab to go into each nostril,  </text><text start="38.88" dur="1.452">rotating five times.</text><text start="40.332" dur="3.057">You have to go about 
half an inch to three quarters of an inch.</text><text start="43.389" dur="3.011">A great thing to remember is about 
the size of the tip of your pinky.</text><text start="48.72" dur="4.255">One, two, three, four, five.</text><text start="52.975" dur="2.351">Though it doesn&#39;t hurt, it 
does feel really funny.</text><text start="55.326" dur="7.009">Now we&#39;ll go to the next nostril - one, two, three, four, five.</text><text start="62.335" dur="3.025">We&#39;ll go ahead and put it back into the wrapper for later use.</text><text start="70.32" dur="3.04">The next part we&#39;re going to 
use is the liquid in the dropper.  </text><text start="73.36" dur="2.24">Make sure to tap it three times on a hard surface.  </text><text start="76.4" dur="1.806">One, two, three.</text><text start="78.206" dur="7.634">You&#39;ll go ahead and open up the orange part and set that aside on a clean surface.</text><text start="86.64" dur="1.76">At this point, you&#39;ll go ahead and grab your swab.</text><text start="92.96" dur="3.92">Place the swab into the liquid 
and you&#39;re going to turn 15 times. </text><text start="97.6" dur="4.51">1, 2... 13, 14, 15.</text><text start="102.11" dur="1.546">Next is a crucial part.</text><text start="103.656" dur="3.248">You&#39;re going to squeeze the bottom in order to squeeze the swap as you pull out,</text><text start="106.904" dur="2.376">making sure you get every last bit of the collection.</text><text start="112" dur="1.84">Now you can throw away your swab.</text><text start="117.2" dur="2.96">Go ahead and grab your cap, replace it</text><text start="123.04" dur="1.6">and you can set this aside for right now.</text><text start="126.96" dur="5.04">The test kit itself has a collection sample 
portion, which requires three drop of the  </text><text start="132" dur="5.512">liquid, as well as the test results. You&#39;ll 
see a C and a T.</text><text start="137.512" dur="3.398">It&#39;s imperative that you get a line at the C,</text><text start="140.91" dur="2.93">which is the control, which lets you know that the test is working itself.</text><text start="144.64" dur="4">Yf you don&#39;t get a C with the 
three drops within the 15 minutes,  </text><text start="148.64" dur="3.36">your test sample is no longer valid 
and you have to use another test.</text><text start="155.76" dur="2.88">Grab your dropper and this time, 
you&#39;re going to take off the top cap.</text><text start="160.96" dur="3.414">You&#39;re going to instill three drops into the 
collection chamber of your kit.</text><text start="165.51" dur="4.057">One, two, three.</text><text start="172.88" dur="1.986">Now comes the hardest part and that&#39;s waiting.</text><text start="174.866" dur="3.791">The best thing to do is to set a timer on your phone for 15 minutes.</text><text start="178.657" dur="3.903">After 15 minutes, you can read your results. You&#39;ll look for</text><text start="183.12" dur="1.105">one of two things.</text><text start="184.225" dur="3.301">You&#39;ll look for a line at the C, which is a control</text><text start="187.526" dur="3.034">and then if you&#39;re positive, you&#39;ll see a line at 
the T,</text><text start="190.56" dur="1.457">which is your test results.</text><text start="192.017" dur="3.33">It doesn&#39;t matter how faint or how bright the result is,</text><text start="195.347" dur="4.159">but if you have that line at the T, then your test is positive for COVID-19.</text><text start="199.506" dur="4.11">If your test is positive, be sure 
to isolate yourself from your friends and family</text><text start="203.616" dur="1.789">and maintain proper precautions -</text><text start="205.405" dur="2.255">washing your hands and wearing a mask.</text><text start="207.66" dur="4.274">If your symptoms worsen, meaning shortness of breath or you can&#39;t get enough air in,</text><text start="211.934" dur="3.215">be sure to go to your local emergency department.</text></transcript>

tags: pandemic;pandemics;black death;flu pandemic;1918 flu;spanish flu;covid 19;covid;covid pandemic;global pandemic;disease;illness;health;public health;disease outbreak;epidemic;endemic;epidemiology;probability;future pandemic;virus;spillover;pathogens;immunity;animal viruses;contact tracing;vaccines;antiviral drugs;pandemic prevention;pandemic readiness;education;animation;igor coric;artrake studio;TED;TED-Ed;TED Ed;Teded;Ted Education
captions:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="6.919" dur="1.21">The Black Death.</text><text start="8.379" dur="1.835">The 1918 Flu Pandemic.</text><text start="10.339" dur="1.168">COVID-19.</text><text start="11.883" dur="3.545">We tend to think of these catastrophic, 
world-changing pandemics</text><text start="15.428" dur="2.294">as very unlikely events.</text><text start="18.389" dur="2.503">But between 1980 and 2020,</text><text start="20.892" dur="3.837">at least three diseases emerged 
that caused global pandemics.</text><text start="24.729" dur="4.921">COVID-19, yes, but also 
the 2009 swine flu and HIV/AIDS.</text><text start="29.942" dur="2.378">Disease outbreaks are surprisingly common.</text><text start="32.528" dur="1.544">Over the past four centuries,</text><text start="34.072" dur="3.128">the longest stretch of time 
without a documented outbreak</text><text start="37.2" dur="4.296">that killed at least 10,000 people
was just four years.</text><text start="42.038" dur="2.169">As bad as these smaller outbreaks are,</text><text start="44.207" dur="3.086">they’re far less deadly than
a COVID-19-level pandemic.</text><text start="47.627" dur="4.629">In fact, many people born after 
the 1918 flu lived their entire lives</text><text start="52.256" dur="3.295">without experiencing
a similar world-changing pandemic.</text><text start="55.843" dur="2.253">What’s the probability that you do, too?</text><text start="58.387" dur="2.253">There are several ways 
to answer this question.</text><text start="60.64" dur="1.668">You could look at history.</text><text start="62.308" dur="2.878">A team of scientists and engineers 
who took this approach</text><text start="65.186" dur="5.422">catalogued all documented epidemics 
and pandemics between 1600 and 1950.</text><text start="70.817" dur="2.085">They used that data to do two things.</text><text start="73.152" dur="3.587">First, to graph the likelihood 
that an outbreak of any size</text><text start="76.739" dur="3.128">pops up somewhere in the world 
over a set period of time.</text><text start="80.409" dur="4.171">And second, to estimate the likelihood
that that outbreak would get large enough</text><text start="84.58" dur="2.753">to kill a certain percentage
of the world&#39;s population.</text><text start="87.708" dur="3.629">This graph shows that while huge
pandemics are unlikely,</text><text start="91.587" dur="1.627">they&#39;re not that unlikely.</text><text start="94.048" dur="2.961">The team used these two distributions
to estimate that the risk</text><text start="97.009" dur="4.338">of a COVID-19-level pandemic 
is about 0.5% per year,</text><text start="101.347" dur="2.711">and could be as high as 1.4%</text><text start="104.058" dur="3.087">if new diseases emerge 
more frequently in the future.</text><text start="108.104" dur="1.793">And we’ll come back to those numbers,</text><text start="109.897" dur="3.045">but first, let’s look at another way
to estimate the likelihood</text><text start="112.942" dur="1.293">of a future pandemic:</text><text start="114.235" dur="1.877">modeling one from the ground up.</text><text start="116.529" dur="4.296">For most pandemics to happen, a pathogen,
which is a microbe that can cause disease,</text><text start="120.825" dur="5.547">has to spill over from its normal host by
making contact with and infecting a human.</text><text start="126.497" dur="2.753">Then, the pathogen has to spread widely,</text><text start="129.25" dur="3.629">crossing international boundaries
and infecting lots of people.</text><text start="133.713" dur="4.588">Many variables determine whether a given
spillover event becomes a pandemic.</text><text start="138.885" dur="4.296">For example, the type of pathogen, 
how often humans come into close contact</text><text start="143.181" dur="3.461">with its animal reservoir, 
existing immunity, and so on.</text><text start="147.602" dur="4.087">Viruses are prime candidates 
to cause the next big pandemic.</text><text start="151.856" dur="5.756">Scientists estimate that there are about
1.7 million as-yet-undiscovered viruses</text><text start="157.612" dur="2.544">that currently infect mammals and birds,</text><text start="160.156" dur="4.921">and that roughly 40% of these have the
potential to spill over and infect humans.</text><text start="166.162" dur="2.878">A team of scientists built a model
using this information,</text><text start="169.04" dur="3.461">as well as data about the global
population, air travel networks,</text><text start="172.501" dur="3.504">how people move around in communities,
country preparedness levels,</text><text start="176.005" dur="2.419">and how people might respond to pandemics.</text><text start="178.799" dur="3.838">The model generated hundreds of thousands
of virtual pandemics.</text><text start="182.72" dur="2.586">The scientists then used 
this catalog to estimate</text><text start="185.306" dur="3.17">that the probability of another 
COVID-19-level pandemic</text><text start="188.476" dur="3.253">is 2.5 to 3.3% per year.</text><text start="192.563" dur="3.379">To get a sense of how these risks
play out over a lifetime,</text><text start="195.942" dur="3.628">let’s pick a value roughly in the middle
of all these estimates: 2%.</text><text start="199.737" dur="3.003">Now let’s build what’s called 
a probability tree diagram</text><text start="202.74" dur="2.336">to model all possible scenarios.</text><text start="205.243" dur="3.128">The first branch of the tree
represents the first year:</text><text start="208.371" dur="3.92">there’s a 2% probability of experiencing
a COVID-19-level pandemic,</text><text start="212.5" dur="3.92">which means there’s a 98% probability 
of not experiencing one.</text><text start="216.712" dur="1.71">Second branch, same thing,</text><text start="218.589" dur="1.335">Third branch, same.</text><text start="219.924" dur="2.544">And so on, 72 more times.</text><text start="222.718" dur="4.922">There is only one path that results
in a fully pandemic-free lifetime:</text><text start="227.848" dur="4.88">98%, or 0.98,
multiplied by itself 75 times,</text><text start="232.728" dur="2.503">which comes out to roughly 22%.</text><text start="235.856" dur="4.088">So the likelihood of living through 
at least one more COVID 19-level-pandemic</text><text start="239.944" dur="5.63">in the next 75 years 
is 100 minus 22%, or 78%.</text><text start="245.866" dur="1.127">78%!</text><text start="247.451" dur="4.171">If we use the most optimistic
yearly estimate— 0.5%—</text><text start="251.747" dur="3.128">the lifetime probability drops to 31%.</text><text start="255.042" dur="4.129">If we use the most pessimistic one,
it jumps to 92%.</text><text start="259.839" dur="2.669">Even 31% is too high to ignore;</text><text start="262.633" dur="3.212">even if we get lucky, 
future generations might not.</text><text start="266.053" dur="3.712">Also, pandemics are usually
random, independent events:</text><text start="269.765" dur="4.797">so even if the yearly probability 
of a COVID-19-level pandemic is 1%,</text><text start="274.729" dur="2.836">we could absolutely get another
one in ten years.</text><text start="278.607" dur="3.963">The good news is we now have tools 
that make pandemics less destructive.</text><text start="283.154" dur="3.628">Scientists estimated that early warning
systems, contact tracing,</text><text start="286.782" dur="2.461">social distancing, 
and other public health measures</text><text start="289.243" dur="3.253">saved over a million lives 
in just the first six months</text><text start="292.496" dur="2.419">of the COVID-19 pandemic in the US,</text><text start="295.333" dur="3.086">not to mention the millions
of lives saved by vaccines.</text><text start="299.587" dur="2.961">One day, another pandemic
will sweep the globe.</text><text start="302.84" dur="3.462">But we can work to make that day
less likely to be tomorrow.</text><text start="306.552" dur="2.252">We can reduce the risk
of spillover events,</text><text start="308.804" dur="2.461">and we can contain spillovers
that do happen</text><text start="311.265" dur="2.544">so they don’t become full-blown pandemics.</text><text start="314.81" dur="2.461">Imagine how the future might
look if we interacted</text><text start="317.271" dur="1.919">with the animal world more carefully,</text><text start="319.19" dur="4.337">and if we had well-funded, open-access 
global disease monitoring programs,</text><text start="323.527" dur="2.92">AI-powered contact tracing
and isolation measures,</text><text start="326.447" dur="3.295">universal vaccines, 
next-generation antiviral drugs,</text><text start="329.742" dur="2.127">and other tech we haven&#39;t even thought of.</text><text start="332.078" dur="3.003">It’s in our power to change 
these probabilities.</text><text start="335.206" dur="3.295">So, we have a choice: we could do nothing
and hope we get lucky.</text><text start="338.501" dur="2.252">Or we could take the threat 
seriously enough</text><text start="340.753" dur="2.419">that it becomes a self-defeating prophecy.</text><text start="343.672" dur="1.961">Which future would you rather live in?</text></transcript>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?><transcript><text start="0.29" dur="1.55">- Hi, I&#39;m doctor Seema Yasmin</text><text start="1.84" dur="3.17">and from 2011 to 2013, I was an officer</text><text start="5.01" dur="1.87">in the Epidemic Intelligence Service,</text><text start="6.88" dur="3">so today I&#39;m gonna match
the timeline of Contagion</text><text start="9.88" dur="2.068">with the timeline of COVID-19.</text><text start="11.948" dur="1.882">[contemplative music]</text><text start="13.83" dur="1.7">Contagion starts on day two,</text><text start="15.53" dur="2.49">and we see Gwyneth
Paltrow&#39;s character is sick</text><text start="18.02" dur="2.1">and then a montage of
other sick civilians,</text><text start="20.12" dur="3.78">all demonstrating symptoms
within one day of transmission.</text><text start="23.9" dur="1.92">Everyone we see who gets sick with this</text><text start="25.82" dur="2.12">has a cough, a fever, seizures,</text><text start="27.94" dur="2.69">and then dies within three to four days.</text><text start="30.63" dur="1.77">The virus in Contagion is fictional.</text><text start="32.4" dur="2.5">It&#39;s called MEV-1, but it is a hybrid</text><text start="34.9" dur="3.75">of two real life infections,
influenza and nipah.</text><text start="38.65" dur="2.65">Nipah is a real life
virus, a very serious one,</text><text start="41.3" dur="2.22">that can cause fever, shortness of breath,</text><text start="43.52" dur="2.68">swelling of the brain, coma, and seizures.</text><text start="46.2" dur="2.47">The illness caused by
MEV-1 is very different</text><text start="48.67" dur="2.76">to COVID-19, where people
get sick over the course</text><text start="51.43" dur="1.69">of two to 14 days.</text><text start="53.12" dur="2.75">And unlike the fictional
virus in Contagion,</text><text start="55.87" dur="3.541">death from COVID-19 isn&#39;t
typically so sudden.</text><text start="59.411" dur="0.94">- [Man] Honey?</text><text start="60.351" dur="1.504">Oh, Beth, Beth, hey.</text><text start="61.855" dur="1.595">[contemplative music]</text><text start="63.45" dur="2.02">- So in this scene, we&#39;re
looking at day five,</text><text start="65.47" dur="2.07">which is the day that the
World Health Organization</text><text start="67.54" dur="1.93">is notified of the outbreak.</text><text start="69.47" dur="2.31">- [Announcer] What we
are hearing from Beijing</text><text start="71.78" dur="1.7">is that the outbreak is contained</text><text start="73.48" dur="2.18">to the Chrysanthemum Complex in Hong Kong.</text><text start="75.66" dur="2.75">- We&#39;re also looking
at samples from London.</text><text start="78.41" dur="0.88">Two clusters--</text><text start="79.29" dur="2.89">- Here&#39;s the first time that
they use the word cluster</text><text start="82.18" dur="2.26">and that can refer to
cases that are literally</text><text start="84.44" dur="2.65">clustered together in time and place.</text><text start="87.09" dur="2.18">We still don&#39;t know who
was the first person</text><text start="89.27" dur="2.29">to become infected with SARS-CoV-2</text><text start="91.56" dur="2.26">and when that was, but we do know</text><text start="93.82" dur="3.28">that Chinese officials alerted
the World Health Organization</text><text start="97.1" dur="2.63">on December 31st of 2019.</text><text start="99.73" dur="3.18">Then it would be day 21
when the United States</text><text start="102.91" dur="2.157">identified its first cases.</text><text start="105.067" dur="2.363">[contemplative music]</text><text start="107.43" dur="2.45">On day six in Contagion, the CDC learns</text><text start="109.88" dur="3.98">of a cluster of cases at an
elementary school in Minnesota.</text><text start="113.86" dur="1.9">- There&#39;s a cluster in
an elementary school.</text><text start="115.76" dur="3.55">- And we start hearing here
some very familiar language.</text><text start="119.31" dur="1.967">- We&#39;re isolating the sick
and quarantining those</text><text start="121.277" dur="1.453">who we believe were exposed.</text><text start="122.73" dur="2.19">- And that&#39;s exactly what
happened here in the U.S.</text><text start="124.92" dur="1.89">People who had symptoms were isolated</text><text start="126.81" dur="2.46">from others and those
